headline: Treasury to Sell $60 Billion of Debt on Monday
summary: The Treasury Department plans to sell $60 billion in short-term bills on Monday, including $30 billion of 13-week and $30 billion of 26-week bills.

headline: Putting Vegetables on Top
summary: A number of top chefs, while still offering meat dishes, are placing vegetables center stage, offering creative vegetable dishes and haute vegetarian tasting menus.

headline: Russell 2000 Falls 3% on the Week
summary: Small-capitalization stocks slumped Friday as concerns about the economic recovery flared up following unsettling data, with energy and consumer-related companies among the top decliners.

summary: A roundup of regional news

headline: Top Texas Criminal Judge Will Remain on Bench
summary: A Texas judge accused of turning away a death-row inmate's appeal was issued a warning and will get to keep her job.

headline: Syria's Monumental Umayyad Mosque
summary: In the middle of Damascus's old city, one of Syria's most famous historic and religious monuments stands: the Umayyad Mosque. The mosque is over 1,300 years old and after many centuries and civilizations, it continues to speak volumes for its surrounding cultures, both past and present.

headline: Principal's Disdain for Regulation Blasted After Drowning
summary: Teachers at the Columbia Secondary School for Math, Science, & Engineering have blasted Principal Jose Maldonado-Rivera for circumventing Department of Education regulations, calling his behavior cavalier.

headline: Inside the Jaguar XK
summary: When Rumble Seat's Dan Neil drove the Jaguar XK, he found people halting their conversations to check out that hunk of sleek metal he was cruising in. A look at what makes the car so eye-catching.

headline: Dining Elsewhere
summary: None

headline: A Family-Friendly Paris Grande Dame
summary: Le Bristol Hotel, first opened in 1925, opened a luxurious new wing last year with 26 rooms and suites, some with views of the Eiffel Tower. The hotel's Les Enfants program offers special treats and amenities for kids.

headline: Crude Oil Slips on Growth Concerns
summary: Lackluster corporate earnings and a weak reading on consumer sentiment weighed on the commodity.

headline: British Open: Round Two
summary: Players battled strong winds on the "Old Lady" Friday during round two of the British Open.

headline: Google Buys Metaweb
summary: Google Inc. on Friday said it bought Metaweb, an Internet information database start-up, in order to improve its core Internet-search business.

headline: Japanese Stocks Tumble 2.9%
summary: A stronger yen sent Japanese shares to their biggest percentage loss in more than a month on Friday, leading most Asian markets lower.

headline: Iraq Hotel Fire Kills at Least 24
summary: A fire raged overnight at a hotel in northern Iraq, killing more than two dozen people, including some foreign workers.

headline: Candover's Search for Salvation
summary: Candover Investments shareholders have had a terrible crisis—and it isn't over yet for the U.K.-listed private-equity group.

headline: Gizmodo to Cooperate With Probe Into Lost iPhone Prototype
summary: Gizmodo reached agreement with California authorities over access to some computer and other material related to an investigation of how the website obtained a prototype of the new Apple iPhone months before its release.

headline: Goldman Shares Jump After SEC Deal
summary: The investment bank's settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission lifted the major risk for the stock.

headline: Contador Turns On the Jets in Late Climb
summary: The Tour de France's defending champion used a late surge up the race's steepest climb to shave 10 seconds off the lead of Andy Schleck.

headline: Medicare Fraud Bust Yields 94 Arrests
summary: Ninety-four medical professionals around the U.S. have been charged for their alleged involvement in a scheme to submit $251 million of false claims to Medicare.

headline: Labor Open to New Korea Trade Deal
summary: The head of the AFL-CIO said he would support an altered free-trade deal with South Korea if the pact reduces nontariff barriers in Korea and protects workers' rights.

headline: U.S. Geologist Jailed in China Appeals
summary: Xue Feng, a U.S. geologist convicted this month of trading in Chinese state secrets, has appealed to a Beijing court to overturn his eight-year sentence.

headline: Strike Threat at U.K. Airport Operator
summary: U.K. airport operator BAA has been given seven days notice of a strike ballot in a dispute over pay by the labor union Unite, the same union that is representing striking cabin crew at British Airways.

headline: Japanese Yields Flat; 1% by Month End?
summary: Yields on Japanese bond yields ended little changed Friday as investors held back ahead of key U.S. events and a Japanese holiday on Monday.

headline: Europe Earnings Sidestep Economic Pain
summary: Second-quarter earnings per share for constituents of the Stoxx Europe 600 index are projected to grow 26%, despite a tumultuous spring in Europe.

headline: Grading the Bill
summary: Experts like Paulson, Pitt and Roubini offer report cards for the financial overhaul. Plus, how would you grade the bill?

headline: Mercedes-Benz SLS Lands in India
summary: Mercedes-Benz has made much of how its gull-winged sports car, the SLS AMG, resembles a plane as much as a car. Either way, it landed New Delhi on Friday at a sale price of 20 million rupees - 25 million rupees.

headline: India's Colorful Headwear
summary: They are huge, small, simple or outright ostentatious: Headwear in India forms a very important part of the national attire. Some design snapshots.

headline: Infosys Shuts Down Bangkok Back Office
summary: Infosys Technologies has shut down its Bangkok back office as it was unable to scale up operations there, the company's chief executive Kris Gopalakrishnan said.

headline: Headbutts Prompt Tour Expulsion
summary: Thursday at the Tour de France saw a wild finish featuring a series of headbutts that helped clear the way for stage winner Mark Cavendish.

headline: Senate Probes Any BP Ties to Bomber's Release
summary: A Senate panel will hold a hearing on Scotland's decision last year to release convicted Lockerbie bomber al-Megrahi, the latest example of how the Gulf of Mexico oil spill has dredged up old problems for BP.

headline: Toyota to Build Brazil Plant
summary: Toyota will build a second auto assembly plant in Brazil, speeding up its shift in focus toward emerging markets as recalls limit its growth potential in the U.S.

headline: TSMC Plans $9 Billion in Spending
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. plans to spend more than $9.34 billion to invest in a new plant and 8,000 staff.

headline: Daimler Inks China JV
summary: Daimler signed a long-awaited contract for a truck joint venture with China's Beiqi Foton Motor Co.as part of its growth strategy in emerging markets.

headline: Sage Appoints New CEO
summary: Sage appointed its European and Asian boss, Guy Berruyer, as its new CEO to succeed Paul Walker, who has been at the helm of the U.K.'s biggest software firm for 16 years.

headline: Regulator Probes Zijin
summary: Zijin Mining Group, China's biggest gold producer by capacity, said that China's securities regulator is looking into the company's disclosure that one of its copper plants in eastern China is leaking acidic waste water.

headline: China's Yuan Overhaul Changes Little
summary: Four weeks is too short a time to judge the full effect of China's new system, but so far it appears the promised overhaul of its currency system has actually changed little.

headline: Port Authority Cuts Its Copters
summary: Port Authority officials ordered its two-helicopter patrol permanently grounded, a move they say will save the agency millions of dollars a year.

headline: Starr Penthouse Goes at Discount
summary: A penthouse apartment that Kenneth I. Starr, the financial adviser accused of defrauding celebrity clients, once planned to buy for $13.9 million has found a new owner, who will pay 19% less for the property.

headline: Navigating EU Plans on Financial Rules
summary: The EU's agenda to boost financial regulation has many moving parts, some of which are moving more slowly than its supporters hoped. A look at where things stand, as Brussels gets ready to embark on its summer recess.

headline: Avandia on Trial
summary: An FDA review panel shows more wisdom than the drug's critics.

headline: Vatican Toughens Rules on Abuse Cases
summary: The Vatican tightened its rules for disciplining cases of alleged sexual abuse, marking the first time it has changed church laws to address the sexual-abuse scandal that has opened Pope Benedict XVI to widespread scrutiny.

headline: Darrell M. West: We Need an Einstein Immigration Policy
summary: When Americans see the benefits of a 'brain gain,' they'll view newcomers more favorably.

headline: Money-Fund Assets Decline
summary: Assets in money-market funds declined $13.12 billion in the latest week as nearly each fund category posted outflows.

headline: Filmmakers Root for 'Inception' Hit
summary: Warner Bros.'s new thriller 'Inception' strives to attract moviegoers with something that almost nobody in sequel-made Hollywood aims for these days: originality.

headline: Rebuilding New Orleans
summary: Leonard Riggio, the founder and chairman of Barnes & Noble and his wife will build their 50th home for New Orleans families who lost their homes after Hurricane Katrina. The couple committed $20 million after the hurricane.

headline: Pure Joy: Hitting the Sweet Spot
summary: Connecting on a well-struck ball is the biggest rush in golf—so why is it such an elusive one?

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for July 16, 2010.

headline: Two Kings Make a Winning Hand
summary: Few companies can afford so labor-intensive a production as "The Madness of King George III," but The Old Globe is bringing it off with seeming effortlessness—and throwing in "The Taming of the Shrew" for good measure.

headline: Down Demand, Uncertain Future
summary: As sales of shrimp and crab from the Gulf Coast continue to decline, businesses are concerned about their long-term future.

headline: La Mode Berlin
summary: Berlin fashion week tries to get on the fashion map.

headline: Goldman Wins Big With Deal
summary: For Goldman Sachs, the settlement with the SEC clears the way for a possibly dramatic rerating of its stock. But a swift ascent isn't certain.

headline: Kazakhstan Probes Chevron Venture
summary: Kazakhstan's financial police launched a criminal probe into an oil project led by Chevron, the latest of several moves to increase pressure on energy ventures that had until recently enjoyed a special status.

headline: Flushing Rings Up Retailers
summary: Queens has had only one regional shopping mall—until now. In the business district of Flushing, Sky View Center, an 800,000-square-foot shopping mall, has started to open its doors.

headline: Sales Boost Novartis Results
summary: Novartis reported a sharp rise in second-quarter net profit on healthy drug sales and cost cuts, prompting the Swiss drug giant to lift its full-year sales guidance.

headline: Senate Panel Backs NASA Space Plan
summary: The Senate Commerce Committee, capping months of intense debate over the future of NASA's manned-exploration program, unanimously approved a $19 billion bill giving the White House most of what it sought to outsource space transportation.

headline: Travelers, BofA Drag on Dow
summary: The Dow industrials snapped a seven-day winning streak, despite a late-session boost from news about a halt in the BP oil leak and expectations of an SEC settlement with Goldman Sachs.

headline: GE Bank Sale: $1.9 Billion
summary: Colombian banking conglomerate Grupo Aval said it will buy Central American banking firm BAC-Credomatic for $1.9 billion from General Electric.

headline: Democrats Rake In Campaign Dollars
summary: It's a good time to be a Democrat—at least in New York. The party's pick for governor, Attorney General Andrew Cuomo, and incumbent U.S. Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, posted strong fund-raising figures.

headline: Madoff-Suit Ruling Favors J.P. Morgan
summary: A judge dismissed a lawsuit against J.P. Morgan Chase that claimed the bank knew about a fraud committed by Bernard Madoff but continued to provide his company banking services to perpetuate the scheme.

headline: Auto Industry Fights Safety Bill
summary: The auto industry pushed back against proposed U.S. vehicle-safety legislation, urging lawmakers to kill provisions industry officials said would raise car prices and expose companies to more lawsuits.

headline: Verenium Jumps 30%; Arena Shifts Into Reverse
summary: Small-capitalization stocks fell as signs of a cooling economy sent some assets sliding.

headline: Steinbrenner Was a Very Loyal Alum, Too
summary: Regarding Allen Barra's "The Yankee Capitalist" (Leisure & Arts, July 14): Growing up in California, I never thought I'd be a Yankee fan, but attending Culver Military Academy changed that. It wasn't that the Steinbrenner Athletic Center there made visiting teams wish they attended school in northern Indiana; it wasn't that the Yankee trainers stocked the gym better than most colleges; it was the thoughtfulness that went into sending touring bands or shows through Culver on their way to or from Chicago, knowing that an alum remembered "how cold and forlorn the winters in the Midwest could be." George Steinbrenner's generosity was without fanfare, without expectations—just pure and simply from the heart.

headline: The Blame Game Starts Early
summary: JOHN FUND ON THE TRAILThe White House and House Democrats go to war.

headline: Staff Turns Against Principal in Drowning
summary: A report that led to the firing of a first-year teacher over the drowning of a 12-year-old Harlem girl has led angry staff members to say the school's principal should bear more of the blame.

headline: Far From Power Lunch
summary: Joseph Leonard, a nearly year-old cafe on a leafy corner of the West Village, trafficks in humility chic: weathered wood, whitewashed brick, blue-checked napkins and mismatched silver.

headline: Volvo Deal Sparks Shake-Up
summary: The pending sale of Volvo Cars from Ford to China's Zhejiang Geely  is sparking leadership changes across the companies.

headline: Movie Review: 'Toy Story 3'
summary: Pixar's at the top of its highflying game in "Toy Story 3," while "Cyrus" offers sparkling surfaces of a seriously skewed triangle.

summary: In a world of climate-change doomsayers, the Discovery Channel introduces us to the scientists who are working on tomorrow's energy sources today.

summary: Key questions for business and consumers will remain unresolved until details of the new regulations are written.
